para.paratext: O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(d)(2) provides:
Admissions shall not be excluded by the hearsay rule. An admission is a statement offered against a party which is:
The party's own statement, in either an individual or representative capacity;
A statement of which the party has manifested an adoption or belief in its truth;
A statement by a person authorized by the party to make a statement concerning the subject;

A statement by the party's agent or employee, but not including any agent of the state in a criminal proceeding, concerning a matter within the scope of the agency or employment, made during the existence of the relationship; or

A statement by a coconspirator of a party during the course and in furtherance of the conspiracy, including a statement made during the concealment phase of a conspiracy. A conspiracy need not be charged in order to make a statement admissible under this subparagraph.

The contents of the statement shall be considered but shall not alone be sufficient to establish the declarant's authority under subparagraph (C) of this paragraph, the agency or employment relationship and scope thereof under subparagraph (D) of this paragraph, or the existence of the conspiracy and the participation therein of the declarant and the party against whom the statement is offered under subparagraph (E) of this paragraph.

Admissions are an opposing party's out-of-court statements or conduct that is inconsistent with his position in the present litigation.[1] It is not necessary to show that the statements were against the party's interest when made.[2] They are admissible as positive evidence of the fact asserted. Moreover, admissions may be admitted even though they contain prejudicial elements and may not be entirely fair.[3] They are especially powerful because they are admissible as an exception to the hearsay rule even if they are not based on the party's personal knowledge[4] and even if they express an opinion the party is not qualified to give.[5]
The entire conversation connected with an admission is admissible into evidence.[6]

Once some portion of a party's out of court statement is introduced, the party has a right under O.C.G.A. § 24-8-822 to place the statement in context by introducing the entire statement. “Of course, … [a] party may explain his out-of-court admission or statement … and it [is] for the jury to say whether he had done so, or to what extent.”[7]

A guilty plea in a criminal action may be an admission in a civil action.[8] However, the Georgia Court of Appeals held in Thompson v. Hill[9] that a guilty plea may be rebutted by testimony that the plea was predicated upon a misapprehension of law or fact. Georgia law which held a “self-serving” out-of-court statement inadmissible is retired.[10]
Testimony of a cellmate regarding information shared by the defendant about the murders and kidnapping of a victim was admissible since it was an admission against his penal interest.[11]

Testimony of the plaintiff's daughter that a nurse told her that her mother had fallen on her urine which was being cleaned by other employees of the hospital when she walked around the bed because the mother thought they were finished cleaning the urine, and that the nurse laughed when recounting the incident, was admissible as an admission of a party opponent.[12]

However, testimony regarding the contents of a piece of paper that detailed a conversation with a company was not admissible as an admission against a party opponent because the person testifying could not testify that the company's logo was on the paper.[13]

In Ray v. State,[14] the Court of Appeals held that a co-defendant's hearsay statements incriminating a defendant may be admissible at trial under the co-conspirator exception to hearsay and do not violate the Confrontation Clause even if the co-conspirator does not testify if the statements are not “testimonial” in nature. The court found that a statement is testimonial if its purpose is to establish evidence that could be used in future prosecution. Because the statements in Ray were made during the conspiracy, they were not “testimonial” and therefore admissible under this exception.

Lawhorne, 130 Ga. App. 314, 203 S.E.2d 292 (1973); Thompson v. Hill, 143 Ga. App. 272, 238 S.E.2d 271 (1977); Kickasola v. Jim Wallace Oil Co., 144 Ga. App. 758, 242 S.E.2d 483 (1978).

Compare Willis v. Integrity Nat. Life Ins. Co., 119 Ga. App. 871, 169 S.E.2d 175 (1969), where the guilty plea of a third party to manslaughter of the insured was not admissible in a suit on the policy by the beneficiary.

Any conduct may be an admission as in Riden v. State, 151 Ga. App. 654, 261 S.E.2d 409 (1979); Carolina Cas. Ins. Co. v. Davalos, 154 Ga. App. 776, 269 S.E.2d 897 (1980), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 246 Ga. 746, 272 S.E.2d 702 (1980) (guilty plea to traffic violation).
Even though the defendant did not plead guilty, admissions made during the hearing in traffic court were held admissible in Cannon v. Rithmire, 156 Ga. App. 360, 274 S.E.2d 746 (1980).
